quote: The skip connections have proved eﬀective in recovering ﬁne-grained details of the target objects; generating segmentation masks with ﬁne details even on complex background.
The re-designed skip pathways aim at reducing the semantic gap between the feature maps of the encoder and decoder sub-networks.

The underlying hypothesis behind our architecture is that the model can more eﬀectively capture ﬁne-grained details of the foreground objects when high-resolution feature maps from the encoder network are gradually enriched prior to fusion.
To address the need for more accurate segmentation in medical images, we present UNet++, a new segmentation architecture based on nested and dense skip connections.
As a result, UNet++ generates four segmentation maps given an input image, which will be further averaged to generate the final segmentation map.
We evaluated UNet++ using four medical imaging datasets covering lung nodule segmentation, colon polyp segmentation, cell nuclei segmentation, and liver segmentation.
Our experiments demonstrated that UNet++ with deep supervision achieved an average IoU gain of 3.9 and 3.4 points over U-Net and wide U-Net, respectively.
Deep supervision also enables more accurate segmentation particularly for lesions that appear at multiple scales such as polyps in colonoscopy videos.
U-net: Convolutional networks for biomedical image segmentation.
